title: NEW DELHI: Framing the demonetisation debate as a battle between the “
text:
NEW DELHI: Framing the demonetisation debate as a battle between the “honest and dishonest“, PM Narendra Modi sought to expand BJP’s political appeal among the middle class, poor and marginalised sections ahead of the Budget and polls in five states.
The political messaging in the PM’s New Year eve address on Saturday evening presented demonetisation as intended to ensure taxes recovered from large suppressed incomes benefit the socially and economically vulnerable.
He said he would protect the interests of the poor, neo middle class and middle class and promised more action against black money and tax evaders as he injected a strong dose of redistributive rhetoric in his much awaited address.
Pitching demonetisation in distinctly class terms, he said, “You will either laugh or be angry when you hear that official information reveals that only 24 lakh people have incomes of more than Rs 10 lakh a year.“
The PM added, “Would you believe this if you see the big houses and cars in your neighbourhood?“ If you consider the big ci ties, there is hardly any city where you will not find lakhs of people with incomes above Rs 10 lakh,“ the PM said. The PM announced schemes and measures for the poor, farmers, small traders, women and senior citizens that seemed a precursor to the Budget -and a likely campaign theme in assembly polls in UP, Punjab, Uttarakhand, Manipur and Goa -indicating a mix of populism and growth pills.
A day after the deadline for depositing old 500 and 1,000-rupee notes, PM Modi called the demonetization a purification drive during his Saturday speech. (AP photo)
Outlining his redistributive politics, Modi said the pain of demonetisation would be worth the wait if the dishonest were punished, and promised he would not take his eye off the ball, with more measures to curb corruption and unveil black money on the anvil. “The question being asked is what will happen to the dishonest? Law will deal with them strictly.“
Modi described demonetisation as a “historic shuddhi yagna“ that will set the country’s direction in coming years. He said people had sup ported demonetisation despite having to stand in lines for hours to withdraw their own money because they wanted to escape the stifling effect of distortions and ills caused by corruption, black money and fake notes.
Modi elaborated on his previous post-demonetisation speeches, saying the gains from demonetisation, in terms of money that has become part of the formal economy , would be used to benefit the poor and small tradesmen who find it hard to access credit. He said it will be his priority to find ways and means to reward honest citizens while there will be tough action against the unscrupulous. “It is clear that the roads are closed for dishonest people trying to find cunning ways to beat the system,“ he said, adding that he welcomed those joining the mainstream.
The PM said more measures will come to nab tax evaders and black money hoarders with the “power of technology“ forcing the “habitually dishonest“ to change their behaviour.
He spoke of how the country had united against exter nal aggression in wars, but said it was all the more remarkable when people got together to combat an enemy within. “Sociologists and historians in coming days will discuss how people summoned a similar resolve to fight weaknesses and maladies within. Usually , whenever there is a campaign for something noble, government and people are arrayed on opposite sides. This was a unique instance of regime and people partnering each other in the fight for the good,“ he said.
He acknowledged that the scarcity of cash in an economy was problematic but said the domination of cash could lead to far more serious trouble, referring to the parallel economy that is inflationary and relies on black money. – TNN
Nashik mint sends 51m notes to RBI in 24hrs
The Currency Note Press (CNP) in Nashik sent its biggest consignment of currency notes to the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) on New Year’s Eve. The consignment consisted of 51 million notes, including 10 million in the Rs 500 denomination. With this, the CNP crossed the one billion mark in the number of notes released since demonetisation kicked in on November 9. Of the 1.034 billion notes the press has released, 345 million are of the Rs 500 denomination, 370 million of Rs 100, 80 million of Rs 50, 222 million of Rs 20, 15 million of Rs 10 and two million pieces of Re 1.The biggest consignment sent to RBI in one day before this was 43 million pieces on December 23. A source at CNP said that around 19 million pieces of currency notes in various denominations were being printed at the Nashik press every day. – Tushar Pawar
